content.webTitle: Wayne Rooney helps England on and off pitch, says Ross Barkley

fields.headline: Wayne Rooney helps England on and off pitch, says Ross Barkley
fields.bodyText: Ross Barkley believes England will still lean heavily on Wayne Rooney’s experience at this summer’s European Championship and stressed the role the captain will play both on and off the pitch in bringing the best out of a young squad. The emergence of Harry Kane and Jamie Vardy, who have 40 Premier League goals between them this season, and the manner of England’s impressive attacking performance against Germany in Berlin on Saturday has prompted debate over whether Rooney should still command a place in Roy Hodgson’s starting XI. The Manchester United striker is recovering from ligament damage to his right knee, sustained in a defeat at Sunderland last month, and although he has now started running again, he is unlikely to return to his club side until late April. Hodgson suggested on Sunday that it would be unfair for Rooney, who is England’s record goalscorer with 51 and who will be a pundit in the ITV studio at Wembley for England’s match against Holland on Tuesday night, to be “jettisoned in some way” in light of the progress made by Vardy and Kane. Vardy and Daniel Sturridge will start against Holland, with Barkley earning his 21st cap and providing a supply line from midfield in another inexperienced English selection. The Everton playmaker joined his manager in placing his support behind the absent captain, pointing out that Rooney’s influence is felt just as keenly off the pitch as on it. “Wayne is the captain, he leads the side,” Barkley said. “He has the experience and he passes it on to the younger lads in the squad, and he helps us younger lads around the place with the knowledge he has built up in the past tournaments and qualifying stages. That helps us all. “I am still pretty new to this squad but the team mixes really well. The squad is a blend of young lads and a few experienced players. “A few of us younger lads have mixed together in the national age groups over the years, so we know each other really well. “It’s just a great bunch of lads and there are lots of options for the manager. We’ve got a few lads who aren’t even in the squad, like Wayne, and there are goals all around the squad. “That’s good to see because we all know the goals we need can come from anywhere.” Barkley had made an impressive cameo against Germany, entering the fray alongside Vardy 19 minutes from time, with the visitors trailing 2-1, and playing a part in the team’s comeback, which was capped by Eric Dier’s stoppage-time winner. “As a young team, that win will have done our confidence the world of good because we were playing against the world champions,” Barkley added. “To have come from 2-0 down to win 3-2 will give us a lot of belief. It’s great to see but we know we still have a lot to learn and that we have a lot of games before we get to the Euros. “We are staying level-headed and we know we have got to stay focused to keep improving.”
